The Rail Safety Act of 1996 may be cited as the "Rail Safety Act." It includes definitions for various terms. The Rail Safety Act of 1996 may be cited as the "Rail Safety Act." It defines key terms such as Administrator, Passenger cab car, Safety locomotive, Secretary, and Train employee. SEC. 3. HOURS OF SERVICE. The Secretary must establish regulations within 180 days of the Act's enactment, in consultation with the Administrator, regarding duty hour limits for train employees. These regulations must include requirements for work hours and rest periods at least as strict as those in section 21103 of title 49, United States Code, and any other necessary safety measures. The Secretary must establish regulations within 180 days of the Act's enactment, in consultation with the Administrator, regarding duty hour limits for train employees. These regulations must include requirements for work hours and rest periods at least as strict as those in section 21103 of title 49, United States Code, and any other necessary safety measures. In promulgating regulations, the Secretary shall use negotiated rulemaking unless deemed inappropriate. If negotiated rulemaking is appropriate, it will be carried out in accordance with specific procedures. Section 21103 of title 49, United States Code, is repealed, with this subsection taking effect upon the promulgation of final regulations by the Secretary. The Secretary must establish regulations within 180 days of the Act's enactment regarding duty hour limits for train employees. These regulations must include requirements for work hours and rest periods at least as strict as those in section 21103 of title 49, United States Code. The repeal of section 21103 will take effect upon the promulgation of final regulations by the Secretary. SEC. 4. SATELLITE-BASED TRAIN CONTROL SYSTEMS. The Secretary will conduct a study to determine the feasibility of requiring satellite-based train control systems to provide positive train control for railroad systems in the United States by January 1, 2001. If it is not practicable to install an effective satellite-based system by that date, regulations will be promulgated to require an alternative system as soon as possible. The Secretary will promulgate regulations to require the use of automated train control technology as soon as possible after the study on satellite-based train control systems is completed. The Secretary will promulgate regulations requiring the use of automated train control technology, with waivers available for railroad systems implementing a satellite-based system by January 1, 2001. Conditions will be established for these regulations. The Secretary, in consultation with the Administrator, will establish exceptions or conditions for regulations regarding automated train control technology. Railroad systems with waivers must provide necessary information to monitor compliance with waiver conditions. The Secretary may revoke waivers for railroad systems if they do not meet conditions for a satellite-based train control system by January 1, 2001. SEC. 5. AUTOMATIC TRAIN ESCAPE DEVICE STUDY. The Secretary will conduct a study on the feasibility of automatic train escape devices within a year of the Act's enactment. A report with findings will be submitted to Congress, and if deemed necessary, regulations for implementing these devices will be issued within 180 days. The Secretary will promulgate regulations for automatic train escape devices on rail passenger trains soon after conducting a feasibility study as required by the Act. SEC. 6. LOCOMOTIVE FUEL TANKS. The Secretary, in consultation with the Administrator, will establish safety standards for fuel tanks of rail passenger trains within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The regulations may apply only to new locomotives if deemed appropriate.

SEC. 7. PASSENGER CAR CRASH-WORTHINESS. The Secretary, in consultation with the Administrator, will determine whether to promulgate regulations within 1 year of the Act's enactment to protect public safety regarding crash posts, safety locomotives, and crash-worthiness standards for passenger cab cars. If necessary, regulations will be promulgated within 180 days to take effect promptly. The Secretary will determine if regulations are needed to protect public safety for crash posts, safety locomotives, and passenger cab cars. If not necessary, a report will be submitted to Congress explaining the decision. SEC. 8. SIGNAL PLACEMENT. The Secretary will conduct a study on rail signal placement, determining if regulations are needed for signals at rail station exits and visible only to train employees. If regulations are deemed necessary for public safety, they must be promulgated within 180 days of the study's completion. Upon completion of the study on rail signal placement, if the Secretary determines that regulations are not necessary for public safety, a report must be submitted to Congress explaining the decision.
